title: Lower Bounds on the Running Time of Two-Way Quantum Finite Automata and Sublogarithmic-Space Quantum Turing Machines

sections.discussion: In this paper, we established strong lower bounds on the expected running time of 2QCFA, or sublogarithmic-space QTMs, that recognize particular languages with bounded error. In particular, the language Lpâ€‹aâ€‹lsubscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™L_{pal} had been shown by Ambainis and Watrous [ref]2 to be recognizable with bounded error by a single-qubit 2QCFA in expected time 2Oâ€‹(n)superscript2ğ‘‚ğ‘›2^{O(n)}. We have given a matching lower bound: no 2QCFA (of any size) can recognize Lpâ€‹aâ€‹lsubscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™L_{pal} with bounded error in expected time 2oâ€‹(n)superscript2ğ‘œğ‘›2^{o(n)}. Moreover, we have shown that no QTM, that runs in expected time 2n1âˆ’Î©â€‹(1)superscript2superscriptğ‘›1Î©12^{n^{1-\Omega(1)}} and uses space oâ€‹(logâ¡n)ğ‘œğ‘›o(\log n), can recognize Lpâ€‹aâ€‹lsubscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™L_{pal} with bounded error. This latter results is especially interesting, as a deterministic TM can recognize Lpâ€‹aâ€‹lsubscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™L_{pal} using space Oâ€‹(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n) (and, of course, polynomial time); therefore, polynomial time quantum TMs have no (asymptotic) advantage over polynomial time deterministic TMs in terms of the amount of space needed to recognize Lpâ€‹aâ€‹lsubscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™L_{pal}. Our main technical result, TheoremÂ 16, showed that, if a language Lğ¿L is recognized with bounded error by a 2QCFA in expected time Tâ€‹(n)ğ‘‡ğ‘›T(n), then âˆƒaâˆˆâ„>0ğ‘subscriptâ„absent0\exists a\in\mathbb{R}_{>0} (that depends only on the number of states of the 2QCFA) such that Tâ€‹(n)=Î©â€‹(DLâ€‹(n)a)ğ‘‡ğ‘›Î©subscriptğ·ğ¿superscriptğ‘›ğ‘T(n)=\Omega(D_{L}(n)^{a}), where DLsubscriptğ·ğ¿D_{L} is the Dwork-Stockmeyer nonregularity of Lğ¿L. This result is extremely (qualitatively) similar to the landmark result of Dwork and Stockmeyer [10, Lemma 4.3], which showed that, if a language Lğ¿L is recognized with bounded error by a 2PFA in expected time Tâ€‹(n)ğ‘‡ğ‘›T(n), then âˆƒaâˆˆâ„>0ğ‘subscriptâ„absent0\exists a\in\mathbb{R}_{>0} (that depends only on the number of states of the 2PFA) such that Tâ€‹(n)=Î©â€‹(2DLâ€‹(n)a)ğ‘‡ğ‘›Î©superscript2subscriptğ·ğ¿superscriptğ‘›ğ‘T(n)=\Omega(2^{D_{L}(n)^{a}}). We again note that both of these lower bounds are tight. We conclude by stating a few interesting open problems. While our lower bound on the expected running time Tâ€‹(n)ğ‘‡ğ‘›T(n), of a 2QCFA that recognizes a language Lğ¿L, in terms of DLâ€‹(n)subscriptğ·ğ¿ğ‘›D_{L}(n) cannot be improved, it is natural to ask if one could establish a lower bound on Tâ€‹(n)ğ‘‡ğ‘›T(n) in terms of a different hardness measure of Lğ¿L that would be stronger for certain languages. Generalizing the definitions made in SectionÂ 4.1, let â„±â„±\mathcal{F} denote a class of finite automata (e.g., DFA, NFA, 2DFA, etc.), let Lğ¿L be a language over some alphabet Î£Î£\Sigma, and let AL,â‰¤â„±â€‹(n)=minâ¡{|M|:Mâˆˆâ„±â€‹Â andÂ â€‹Lâ€‹(M)âˆ©Î£â‰¤n=Lâˆ©Î£â‰¤n}superscriptsubscriptğ´ğ¿â„±ğ‘›:ğ‘€ğ‘€â„±Â andÂ ğ¿ğ‘€superscriptÎ£absentğ‘›ğ¿superscriptÎ£absentğ‘›A_{L,\leq}^{\mathcal{F}}(n)=\min\{\lvert M\rvert:M\in\mathcal{F}\text{ and }L(M)\cap\Sigma^{\leq n}=L\cap\Sigma^{\leq n}\} denote the smallest number of states of an automaton of type â„±â„±\mathcal{F} that agrees with Lğ¿L on all strings of length at most nğ‘›n. As discussed earlier, AL,â‰¤Dâ€‹Fâ€‹Aâ€‹(n)=DLâ€‹(n)superscriptsubscriptğ´ğ¿ğ·ğ¹ğ´ğ‘›subscriptğ·ğ¿ğ‘›A_{L,\leq}^{DFA}(n)=D_{L}(n), for any language Lğ¿L and for any nâˆˆâ„•ğ‘›â„•n\in\mathbb{N}. Recall that DFA and 2DFA both recognize precisely the regular languages [ref]30, but for some L^âˆˆğ–±ğ–¤ğ–¦^ğ¿ğ–±ğ–¤ğ–¦\widehat{L}\in\mathsf{REG}, the smallest 2DFA that recognizes L^^ğ¿\widehat{L} might have many fewer states than the smallest DFA that recognizes L^^ğ¿\widehat{L}. In fact, there is a sequence of regular languages (Lk)kâˆˆâ„•subscriptsubscriptğ¿ğ‘˜ğ‘˜â„•(L_{k})_{k\in\mathbb{N}} such that Lksubscriptğ¿ğ‘˜L_{k} can be recognized by a 5â€‹k+55ğ‘˜55k+5-state 2DFA, but any DFA that recognizes Lksubscriptğ¿ğ‘˜L_{k} requires at least kksuperscriptğ‘˜ğ‘˜k^{k} states ; however, this is (essentially) the largest succinctness advantage possible, as any language recognizable by a dğ‘‘d-state 2DFA is recognizable by a (d+2)d+1superscriptğ‘‘2ğ‘‘1(d+2)^{d+1}-state DFA . Of course, for any language Lğ¿L, we have AL,â‰¤2â€‹Dâ€‹Fâ€‹Aâ€‹(n)â‰¤AL,â‰¤Dâ€‹Fâ€‹Aâ€‹(n)superscriptsubscriptğ´ğ¿2ğ·ğ¹ğ´ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ´ğ¿ğ·ğ¹ğ´ğ‘›A_{L,\leq}^{2DFA}(n)\leq A_{L,\leq}^{DFA}(n), âˆ€nfor-allğ‘›\forall n. For certain languages Lğ¿L, we have AL,â‰¤2â€‹Dâ€‹Fâ€‹Aâ€‹(n)â‰ªAL,â‰¤Dâ€‹Fâ€‹Aâ€‹(n)much-less-thansuperscriptsubscriptğ´ğ¿2ğ·ğ¹ğ´ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ´ğ¿ğ·ğ¹ğ´ğ‘›A_{L,\leq}^{2DFA}(n)\ll A_{L,\leq}^{DFA}(n), âˆ€nfor-allğ‘›\forall n; most significantly, this holds for the languages Lpâ€‹aâ€‹lsubscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™L_{pal} and Leâ€‹qsubscriptğ¿ğ‘’ğ‘L_{eq} shown by Ambainis and Watrous [ref]2 to be recognizable with bounded error by 2QCFA in, respectively, expected exponential time and expected polynomial time. In particular, it is easy to show that ALpâ€‹aâ€‹l,â‰¤Dâ€‹Fâ€‹Aâ€‹(n)=2Î˜â€‹(n)superscriptsubscriptğ´subscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™ğ·ğ¹ğ´ğ‘›superscript2Î˜ğ‘›A_{L_{pal},\leq}^{DFA}(n)=2^{\Theta(n)}, ALeâ€‹q,â‰¤Dâ€‹Fâ€‹Aâ€‹(n)=Î˜â€‹(n)superscriptsubscriptğ´subscriptğ¿ğ‘’ğ‘ğ·ğ¹ğ´ğ‘›Î˜ğ‘›A_{L_{eq},\leq}^{DFA}(n)=\Theta(n), and ALpâ€‹aâ€‹l,â‰¤2â€‹Dâ€‹Fâ€‹Aâ€‹(n)=nÎ˜â€‹(1)superscriptsubscriptğ´subscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™2ğ·ğ¹ğ´ğ‘›superscriptğ‘›Î˜1A_{L_{pal},\leq}^{2DFA}(n)=n^{\Theta(1)}; moreover, ALeâ€‹q,â‰¤2â€‹Dâ€‹Fâ€‹Aâ€‹(n)=logÎ˜â€‹(1)â¡(n)superscriptsubscriptğ´subscriptğ¿ğ‘’ğ‘2ğ·ğ¹ğ´ğ‘›superscriptÎ˜1ğ‘›A_{L_{eq},\leq}^{2DFA}(n)=\log^{\Theta(1)}(n) [21, Theorem 3 and Corollary 4]. In fact, this same phenomenon occurs for all the group word problems that we can show [ref]31 are recognized by 2QCFA. Might this be true for all languages recognizable by 2QCFA? If a language Lğ¿L is recognizable with bounded error by a 2QCFA in expected time Tâ€‹(n)ğ‘‡ğ‘›T(n), does a stronger lower bound than Tâ€‹(n)=(AL,â‰¤2â€‹Dâ€‹Fâ€‹Aâ€‹(n))Î©â€‹(1)ğ‘‡ğ‘›superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ´ğ¿2ğ·ğ¹ğ´ğ‘›Î©1T(n)=(A_{L,\leq}^{2DFA}(n))^{\Omega(1)} hold? We have shown that the class of languages recognizable with bounded error by a 2QCFA in expected polynomial time is contained in ğ–«/ğ—‰ğ—ˆğ—…ğ—’ğ–«ğ—‰ğ—ˆğ—…ğ—’\mathsf{L/poly}. This type of dequantization result, which shows that the class of languages recognizable by a particular quantum model is contained in the class of languages recognizable by a particular classical model, is analogous to the Adleman-type  derandomization result ğ–¡ğ–¯ğ–«âŠ†ğ–«/ğ—‰ğ—ˆğ—…ğ—’ğ–¡ğ–¯ğ–«ğ–«ğ—‰ğ—ˆğ—…ğ—’\mathsf{BPL}\subseteq\mathsf{L/poly}. It is natural to ask if our dequantization result might be extended, either to 2QCFA that run in a larger time bound, or to small-space QTM. Note that ğ–«/ğ—‰ğ—ˆğ—…ğ—’={L:AL,=2â€‹Dâ€‹Fâ€‹Aâ€‹(n)=nOâ€‹(1)}={L:AL,â‰¤2â€‹Dâ€‹Fâ€‹Aâ€‹(n)=nOâ€‹(1)}âŠ‹{L:AL,â‰¤Dâ€‹Fâ€‹Aâ€‹(n)=nOâ€‹(1)}ğ–«ğ—‰ğ—ˆğ—…ğ—’conditional-setğ¿superscriptsubscriptğ´ğ¿2ğ·ğ¹ğ´ğ‘›superscriptğ‘›ğ‘‚1conditional-setğ¿superscriptsubscriptğ´ğ¿2ğ·ğ¹ğ´ğ‘›superscriptğ‘›ğ‘‚1superset-of-and-not-equalsconditional-setğ¿superscriptsubscriptğ´ğ¿ğ·ğ¹ğ´ğ‘›superscriptğ‘›ğ‘‚1\mathsf{L/poly}=\{L:A_{L,=}^{2DFA}(n)=n^{O(1)}\}=\{L:A_{L,\leq}^{2DFA}(n)=n^{O(1)}\}\supsetneq\{L:A_{L,\leq}^{DFA}(n)=n^{O(1)}\}. This further demonstrates the value of the preceding open problem, as any improvement in the lower bound on Tâ€‹(n)ğ‘‡ğ‘›T(n) in terms of AL,â‰¤2â€‹Dâ€‹Fâ€‹Aâ€‹(n)superscriptsubscriptğ´ğ¿2ğ·ğ¹ğ´ğ‘›A_{L,\leq}^{2DFA}(n) would directly translate into an improved dequantization result. The seminal paper of Lipton and Zalcstein  showed that, if a finitely generated group GğºG has a faithful finite-dimensional (linear) representation over a field of characteristic 00, then WGâˆˆğ–«subscriptğ‘Šğºğ–«W_{G}\in\mathsf{L} (deterministic logspace). We [ref]31 recently adapted their technique to show that 2QCFA can recognize the word problem WGsubscriptğ‘ŠğºW_{G} of any group GğºG that belongs to a certain (proper) subset of the set of groups to which their result applies: any group GğºG that has a faithful finite-dimensional unitary representation of a certain special type. The requirement, imposed by the laws of quantum mechanics, that the state of the quantum register of a 2QCFA must evolve unitarily, prevents a 2QCFA from (directly) implementing the Lipton-Zalcstein algorithm for any other groups; on the other hand, for those groups GğºG that do have such a representation, these same laws allow a 2QCFA to recognize WGsubscriptğ‘ŠğºW_{G} using only a constant amount of space. The word problem WGsubscriptğ‘ŠğºW_{G} of any group GğºG that lacks such a representation (for example, all Gâˆˆğ’¢vNilpâˆ–ğ’¢vAbğºsubscriptğ’¢vNilpsubscriptğ’¢vAbG\in\mathcal{G}_{\textbf{vNilp}}\setminus\mathcal{G}_{\textbf{vAb}}, or any infinite Kazhdan group, or any group of intermediate growth) seems to be a plausible candidate for a hard problem for 2QCFA (see [ref]31 for further discussion). Is there a finitely generated group GğºG that does not have a faithful finite-dimensional projective unitary representation for which WGâˆˆğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¤ğŸ¤ğ–°ğ–¢ğ–¥ğ– subscriptğ‘Šğºğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¤ğŸ¤ğ–°ğ–¢ğ–¥ğ– W_{G}\in\mathsf{BQE2QCFA}? Concerning those groups with word problem recognizable by a 2QCFA in expected polynomial time, we have shown that, if Gâˆˆğ’¢vAbğºsubscriptğ’¢vAbG\in\mathcal{G}_{\textbf{vAb}}, then WGâˆˆğ–¼ğ—ˆğ–±ğ–°ğ–¯ğŸ¤ğ–°ğ–¢ğ–¥ğ– â„šÂ¯â€‹(2)âŠ†ğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯ğŸ¤ğ–°ğ–¢ğ–¥ğ– subscriptğ‘Šğºsubscriptğ–¼ğ—ˆğ–±ğ–°ğ–¯ğŸ¤ğ–°ğ–¢ğ–¥ğ– Â¯â„š2ğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯ğŸ¤ğ–°ğ–¢ğ–¥ğ– W_{G}\in\mathsf{coRQP2QCFA}_{\overline{\mathbb{Q}}}(2)\subseteq\mathsf{BQP2QCFA} [31, Theorem 1.2]; moreover, if WGâˆˆğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯ğŸ¤ğ–°ğ–¢ğ–¥ğ– subscriptğ‘Šğºğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯ğŸ¤ğ–°ğ–¢ğ–¥ğ– W_{G}\in\mathsf{BQP2QCFA}, then Gâˆˆğ’¢vNilpğºsubscriptğ’¢vNilpG\in\mathcal{G}_{\textbf{vNilp}} (TheoremÂ 28). We have also shown, if WHâˆ‰ğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯ğŸ¤ğ–°ğ–¢ğ–¥ğ– subscriptğ‘Šğ»ğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯ğŸ¤ğ–°ğ–¢ğ–¥ğ– W_{H}\not\in\mathsf{BQP2QCFA}, where Hâˆˆğ’¢vNilpğ»subscriptğ’¢vNilpH\in\mathcal{G}_{\textbf{vNilp}} is the (three-dimensional discrete) Heisenberg group, then the classification of those groups whose word problem is recognizable by a 2QCFA in expected polynomial time would be complete; in particular, we would have WGâˆˆğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯ğŸ¤ğ–°ğ–¢ğ–¥ğ– â‡”Gâˆˆğ’¢vAbâ‡”subscriptğ‘Šğºğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯ğŸ¤ğ–°ğ–¢ğ–¥ğ– ğºsubscriptğ’¢vAbW_{G}\in\mathsf{BQP2QCFA}\Leftrightarrow G\in\mathcal{G}_{\textbf{vAb}} (PropositionÂ 30). This naturally raises the following question. Is there a group Gâˆˆğ’¢vNilpâˆ–ğ’¢vAbğºsubscriptğ’¢vNilpsubscriptğ’¢vAbG\in\mathcal{G}_{\textbf{vNilp}}\setminus\mathcal{G}_{\textbf{vAb}} such that WGâˆˆğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯ğŸ¤ğ–°ğ–¢ğ–¥ğ– subscriptğ‘Šğºğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯ğŸ¤ğ–°ğ–¢ğ–¥ğ– W_{G}\in\mathsf{BQP2QCFA}? In particular, is WHâˆˆğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯ğŸ¤ğ–°ğ–¢ğ–¥ğ– subscriptğ‘Šğ»ğ–¡ğ–°ğ–¯ğŸ¤ğ–°ğ–¢ğ–¥ğ– W_{H}\in\mathsf{BQP2QCFA}, where Hğ»H is the Heisenberg group?
